course.name: Honors Calculus II
course.description: This is the second in the sequence MATH 1023 - MATH 1024 of honors courses in one-variable calculus, with particular emphasis on rigorous mathematical reasoning. Topics include integral calculus, techniques of integration, improper integrals, applications of integrals, infinite series. Some rigorous theoretical results on integration and infinite series will be discussed.
course.prerequisites: MATH 1012 OR MATH 1013 OR MATH 1023
course.exclusions: AL Pure Mathematics; AL Applied Mathematics; MATH 1014, MATH 1020

reviews.comment_teaching:
----------------------------- 𝐋𝐄𝐂𝐓𝐔𝐑𝐄𝐒 -----------------------------

The teaching is very concise and clear, but the speed is very fast. His English accent is good enough for us to follow, and he knows Cantonese as well. You are free to ask him questions after the lecture. There is usually a 5 min break in the middle of a lecture, so your brain can take a rest.

The handwriting is done on GoodNotes with screen recording. If you cannot follow the pace, you can review the lecture by watching the video.

The course content follows mainly Yan Min's notes, but occasionally there will be extra content with supplementary notes. Besides, there will be 1 worksheet per 1-2 lessons that demonstrates some approaches to easier problems.

---------------------------- 𝐓𝐔𝐓𝐎𝐑𝐈𝐀𝐋𝐒 ----------------------------

There is 1 tutorial per week. Some problems are a bit easy, while others are very difficult with long solutions that won't appear in homework or exams. However, I think more explanation can be done on how the solutions are achieved, instead of leaving us the impression that only experienced math students can come up with the solutions. Besides, more effort can be put into selecting the tutorial problems. Sometimes the T.A. just completes one tutorial with easy problems within 15 minutes.

------------------- 𝐅𝐈𝐍𝐀𝐋 𝐑𝐄𝐕𝐈𝐄𝐖 𝐒𝐄𝐒𝐒𝐈𝐎𝐍 -------------------

Before the final exam, there will be a final review session revisiting the concepts, demonstrating some problems, and going through the cheat sheet.
reviews.comment_grading:
------------------------------ 𝐆𝐑𝐀𝐃𝐈𝐍𝐆 ------------------------------

Take the maximum mark such that the total is 100%:

Homework 20%
Midterm 10%-40%
Final 40%-70%

This means you can save your midterm with your final, but not vice versa. Therefore, make sure you put enough effort into preparing for the final exam.

The grade is decent. A range is given to people with 55% total marks or above, and half of the class is in the A range. You secure a B+ if you are above the mean.

-------------------------- 𝐁𝐎𝐍𝐔𝐒 𝐏𝐎𝐈𝐍𝐓𝐒 --------------------------

The homework offers a bonus course point of 0.2 by submitting a LaTeX-generated .pdf file and the original .tex file instead of handwriting. Therefore, you can get a total of 2 total course marks (without the *20% for homework). I think it is worth the time to type LaTeX, as the 2 course marks may be saving you for a higher grade.

You can also earn a bonus course point of 0.2 by finding and reporting a typo in Yan Min's lecture notes, homework, or homework solutions, capped at 2 points. Yan Min's notes contain a decent amount of typos, especially in computation steps, but hard to find in my opinion since the notes are quite long. In contrast, I think typos are easier to be found in Ivan's homework solutions. Some easy ones are missing a "dx", missing the integrand, and missing the term to sum over after the summation symbol.

There were also 2 more bonus marks from:
1. Treasure hunt - Find the secret word from the symbols from each worksheet.
2. Fourier picture gallery - Upload a figure drawn with the Fourier series with varying no. of sin and cosine terms, where the figures are generated with coding, and the Fourier expansion is derived from HW #10 optional problem.

With the highest possible bonus course points of 6, you can get one subgrade higher, so they are worth the time completely.

------------------------------- 𝐄𝐗𝐀𝐌𝐒 -------------------------------

The midterm and final exams are extremely difficult, you will feel like vomiting blood during the exams. The midterm exam kicks off with a very tricky question (What is the meaning of some weird notation?). The final exam offers 1 bonus mark to the 3 closest answers for "At what age did Euler solve the Basel problem?". Then, there are a few short questions, which are already quite difficult for normal people like me.

Then, they are followed by 2-3 computation questions which are where most people get points from. Each is worth around 10 points. For your reference, midterm has definite integrals that require you to apply a few substitutions or integration by part, while final has series computations that require you to apply Abel's Limit Theorem, Fourier series, or given power series of some function.

Afterward, there are 2 long problems with around 4 parts each. These are the most difficult questions that I usually don't know how to do. But by writing something, regardless of correctness, the lenient T.A.s may give at least 1 mark. You can write down the approach to a problem if you failed to work out the exact details, and you will usually get more than half of the marks.

------------------------ 𝐆𝐑𝐀𝐃𝐄 𝐑𝐄𝐋𝐄𝐀𝐒𝐄 ------------------------

Finally, the final exam result and letter grades are quickly released within 24 hours after the final exam, so don't check your result if you think it may affect your performance in other final exams.
reviews.comment_workload:
--------------------------- 𝐇𝐎𝐌𝐄𝐖𝐎𝐑𝐊 ---------------------------

As a student who got 5** in DSE Math Core and 5* in M2, the workload was like an 8-credit course. But given this is an honor course, I would give the workload a D.

There were a total of 10 homework. Each homework would be released each week, containing 4 compulsory long problems and 1 optional problem with 2-4 parts each. But the deadline was usually 3 weeks later, meaning there were 2 weeks of buffer in case you cannot finish it within the first week.

The homework problems require a lot of thinking. Therefore, it's better to form groups to work on the homework, as lots of times, you wouldn't be able to come up with a solution. Usually, the solution only takes not more than 5 steps, so if your unsuccessful attempt is overly complicated, you may be in the wrong direction. It took me around 2-3 days to complete one homework.

However, the homework was very rewarding, not only because they were intellectually stimulating, but compared to MATH 1014 difficulty, you can have a good grasp of the concepts and computations in the topic, but it was completely not enough for handling Ivan's exams.

-------------------------- 𝐁𝐎𝐍𝐔𝐒 𝐏𝐎𝐈𝐍𝐓𝐒 --------------------------

The homework offers a bonus course point of 0.2 by submitting a LaTeX-generated .pdf file and the original .tex file instead of handwriting. This also takes a lot of time, usually within 1 day. I recommend using the online platform Overleaf - https://overleaf.com for its good editor (e.g. highlight brackets, the drop-down list for commands) and auto-save function. If your eyesight is not that good, you can use Mathcha - https://mathcha.io as it is a live LaTeX editor, i.e. you can directly edit the preview of math expressions with LaTeX instead of typing LaTeX code and then compiling it for preview.

If you are a perfectionist, do not fixate on the beauty of LaTeX, make sure you put enough effort into other courses and balance time well while you take this beast.

reviews.author: John
reviews.comment_content:
The course is a much more in-depth version of MATH1014, with emphasis on proof.
At first the definition and test of existence of definite integral will be taught, which is quite hard a part in this course. Fundamental theorem of calculus will be proved.
Then comes the techniques of integration (integration of rational functions and change of variables are subtle), improper integrals and application of integrals (arc length, surface area, volumes, ...).
Infinite series and their convergence (absolute and conditional) will be discussed. Another interesting but hard part of this course.
Fourier series is amazing with many incredible results but relatively easy, but more emphasis will be put on Fourier analysis and uniform convergence, which will not be tested.
Caution: Be punctual for class or just skip it. Don't be late.

reviews.comment_grading:
Grading scheme
Course total = sup { 20α + c₁β + c₂γ + δ | c₁∈[0.1, 0.4], c₂∈[0.4, 0.7], c₁+c₂=0.8 }

α = Homework score in %
There are 10 homework in total, each with 4 problems, each problem worths 30 points. 3 random problems are graded each homework (determined by lucky draw on class), so each homework worths 90 points. So
α = Sum of your homework total / 900

β = Midterm score

γ = Final score

δ = Bonus

There are 4 components in the bonus score system. Maximum attainable score in parentheses.

1) LaTeX bonus (2)
If you submit a .pdf and a .tex file of a reasonably typed LaTeX homework, you get 0.2 bonus points for that homework.

2) Typo for bonus! (2)
Post on the discussion thread on Canvas any mathematical typo you find on Yan Min's Lecture Notes (Ch3 and Ch4 only) and Homework Set and Solutions. Each typo worths 0.2 bonus points and is capped at 2 points.

3) Treasure Hunt (1)
Try to work out the hidden message on Ivan's worksheets and post it on the discussion thread.

4) Fourier Picture Gallery (1)
Optional problem of Homework 10. Think of a picture, and try to plot it using complex Fourier series with a computer program. Post it on the discussion thread.

Maximum bonus attainable = 6

The grading was quite good. Out of 68 students (take or audit), 6 students failed,
30 students (44.1% / 48.4% not counting F) got ≥ A-
51 students got ≥ B- (75% / 82.3%)

See gradebook in the course Canvas page for details.

(P.S. im the supremum of A- 🥲)

Dr. Xiong always urges us to do more exercises because we have to familiar with those questions. reviews.comment_content:
The content of this course is really great. It includes integration and infinite series.

The content of the course is based on a calculus lecture note written by prof. Yan Min. MATH1023 covers chapters 1 and 2 while MATH1024 covers the remaining chapters 3 and 4.

Chapter 3 is on integration, it covers the rigorous definition of integration, techniques and theorems of integration, infinite integral. Many theorems is related to other theorems of  differentiation covered in chapter 2.

Chapter 4 covers infinite series, which is basically a rewrite of the concepts of infinite sequence in chapter 1. Actual topics include the determination of convergence and conditional convergence. Basic techniques of Fourier transformation is also covered.

His teaching and explanations is always clear and is in appropriate depth, which make lectures appealing. His drawing is also funny. Taking his lecture feel satisfying.

reviews.comment_content:
Mainly about integration and series, please refer to other reviews if you want more details. The most important parts are approximations of integrals, improper integrals, convergence of series and Fourier series.
For those who are wondering whether you should take math 1024, here are some suggestions (assume you aim for A range).
Those who have taken 1023: Just continue if you have A range in 1023, otherwise, do not expect you would suddenly improve.
Those who have not taken 1023: Take the course if and only if you meet these criteria:
1. You can get an A/A+ in math 1013 even if you do not attend any lectures and did not do any revision. If you cannot excel in math 1013 with an eye closed, go home.
2. Find some reference materials for math 1024 (lecture notes/ problem sets/ past papers). If you could understand 70% of the notes and do half of the problems correct, 1024 welcomes you. Otherwise, go home.
For those who do not dare to take 1024, but thinks 1014 is too boring, do the following:
1. Find a 1014 class that does not require any attendance.
2. Go to sit in 1024 classes instead. A range in 1014 should not be a problem.
reviews.comment_teaching: Professor Fong tries to make the lessons funny, which he succeeded. Just like other math teachers, there are all sorts of calculation mistakes, which makes the course really fun. Professor Fong explains things in a clear manner, but if you understand nothing when reading the notes yourself, do not expect this to change after the lectures. What you should really do is to learn most of the materials, then use the lectures to clear your doubts.
reviews.comment_grading:
Since a gradebook is already provided downstairs, I am not going to say too much. If you have confirmed that you are eligible for the course, A range is not a problem at all. By saying this, I mean you could skip all classes, do zero revision and still get A range (I do not recommend you to do so though). With some effort, and a slice of luck, you might be able to get A+, which I somehow managed to do it (I do not know why).
Also, the grading speed is horrible in a sense that they could release grades 1 day after the exam, so make yourself prepared for the shock.
reviews.comment_workload:
Weekly problem sets, which changed to bi-weekly after the midterm. Personally, I spend 3-4 hours on each set, 1-2 more extra hours on typesetting it for some bonus points. That should not be too difficult, but make sure you start working at least 5 days before the deadline if you want to finish it all on your own, as thinking time might be very long once you are stuck, and deadlines make people panic.
As for revision, you really should not need any revision, just do as much as you like. If you want to know, I spent about 1 hour on the final exam. Actually, this is the great thing for all math courses: revisions are absolutely useless.
